IRS Code 594 Meaning

IRS Code 594 marks that a return was filed in response to a non-filer situation. It ties the non-filer workflow to an actual filing event, helping you line up CP notices, closing codes, and the posting of Code 150 on an account transcript. For sequencing tips, see the complete guide to reading IRS transcripts.

Try the parser (requires credits)

What is IRS Code 594?

Plain-English definition: Code 594 shows that a previously open non-filer case has been updated to reflect a return filed. It is a closing code that connects non-filer enforcement work to an actual Form 1040 or other return submission.

Common transcript type
Account Transcript
Usually appears near
Codes 590, 597, 599, 150
Typical context
Non-filer case closures when a delinquent return is finally filed
Client-friendly summary
"The IRS shows a return was filed to resolve an earlier missing-return problem."

When does Code 594 appear?

  • After non-filer notices: You may see 594 following CP59, CP63, or similar notices once the taxpayer submits a required return.
  • Alongside late or delinquent filings: Code 594 can appear when a late return is filed to clean up multiple years at once, especially in representation engagements.
  • Paired with assessment activity: Around the same time, you should see Code 150 and possibly Code 290 or 300 as the IRS assesses the liability tied to the filed return.

What does Code 594 usually signal?

If the return was accepted as filed

A clean sequence of 590 or non-filer notices followed by 594 and 150 suggests the IRS accepted the delinquent return and moved the module into normal processing. Your report can highlight this as a resolved non-filer year.

If additional review or adjustment follows

When 594 is followed by 290/300 adjustments, AUR activity, or exam codes, it signals the IRS used the filed return as a starting point but later changed the liability. This nuance should be explained clearly to the client.

What should a tax professional do next?

  1. Match the return to the code sequence: Confirm the filing date, method, and tax year on the return that drove the Code 594 entry.
  2. Check that assessment and balance agree: Review Code 150, any adjustments, and the resulting balance to ensure they match expectations from the filed return.
  3. Document closure of the non-filer issue: In your workpapers and client report, clearly show how Code 594 and related entries resolved the original missing-return problem.

Use the complete guide to reading IRS transcripts as a cross-reference when narrating how a non-filer case moved from 590 to 594 and beyond.

Example: how this looks in a parsed report

Below is a simplified example of how Code 594 might appear when a delinquent return resolves a non-filer case:

Transcript Processing Timeline
Code 590 – No return filed (initial non-filer closure)
Date: 04/15/2024
Code 594 – Return filed (non-filer status updated)
Date: 08/20/2024
Code 150 – Tax return filed and assessed
Date: 09/02/2024

FAQ

What does IRS Code 594 mean?

IRS Code 594 means the IRS updated a non-filer case to show a return was filed for that year. It marks the point where a missing return issue was resolved by an actual filing.

How is Code 594 different from Code 150?

Code 594 is a closing code for the non-filer workflow, while Code 150 is the core assessment entry when the return posts. You need both to understand when the IRS received the return and when it updated the balance.

Does 594 confirm the return was processed?

It confirms the IRS treated the return as filed for non-filer purposes, but you must still verify that assessment and balance entries match the return. Look for Code 150 and check the resulting balance and any adjustments.

What transcript entries should follow?

After 594 you typically see Code 150, potential 290 or 291 adjustments, and then payment or refund activity. In some workflows, Code 599 will also appear to show the non-filer case is fully satisfied.

IRS Code 597 Meaning (Return Not Processed / Pending Review) – For Tax Professionals

IRS Code 597 Meaning

IRS Transcript Codes • Built for 750,000+ U.S. Tax Professionals

IRS Code 597 Meaning

IRS Code 597 is a pending status code that tells you a return has been received by the IRS but is not yet processed or posted to the account. On an account transcript, it signals the return is in review or waiting for processing. This can occur in paper-filing backlogs, e-file rejections, or other delays. For context, see the complete guide to reading IRS transcripts.

Try the parser (requires credits)

What is IRS Code 597?

Plain-English definition: Code 597 appears when the IRS has received a tax return but has not yet processed or posted it to the account. It marks a holding or pending review period, often before a return is fully accepted, posted, or resolved.

Common transcript type
Account Transcript
Usually appears near
Codes 590, 594, 599, 150
Typical context
Return received but not yet processed, backlog, pending review or rejection
Client-friendly summary
"The IRS received a return, but it has not been processed or posted yet."

When does Code 597 appear?

  • After a return is submitted: Code 597 appears when a return is in the IRS's possession but not yet processed.
  • When processing is delayed: You may see 597 for paper returns, amended returns, or e-filed returns in review.
  • Before non-filer closure or assessment: 597 will typically be replaced by 594 (return filed), 599 (case satisfied), or 150 (assessment) once the return is processed.

What does Code 597 usually signal?

If the return is simply delayed

Code 597 is usually a temporary status. It means the IRS has the return but has not yet posted it. This can result from backlogs, manual reviews, or technical errors. Expect 597 to be replaced by 594, 599, or 150 once processing is complete.

If the return is rejected or stuck

If 597 persists for weeks or months, it may indicate a problem. Review e-file acknowledgments, IRS notices, and client copies to determine if a resubmission or follow-up is needed.

What should a tax professional do next?

  1. Verify filing dates and method: Confirm when and how the return was submitted and compare to transcript posting dates.
  2. Check for closure or assessment codes: Look for subsequent 594, 599, or 150 codes to see if the return was eventually posted.
  3. Document open/pending status: In your report, note for the client that the IRS has the return but has not yet processed it. Set a follow-up to check for movement.

Reference the complete guide to reading IRS transcripts for more on sequencing and status checks.

Example: how this looks in a parsed report

Below is a simplified example of Code 597 in a transcript timeline, showing a pending return before processing completes:

Transcript Processing Timeline
Code 590 – No return filed (initial non-filer closure)
Date: 04/15/2024
Code 597 – Return received, pending review
Date: 06/10/2024
Code 594 – Return filed (non-filer status updated)
Date: 08/20/2024
Code 599 – Return processed / case satisfied
Date: 09/05/2024

FAQ

What does IRS Code 597 mean?

IRS Code 597 means the IRS has received a return but has not processed or posted it. It is a pending/handoff code signaling the IRS has the return, but further action is required before final closure or assessment.

What should you check before advising a client?

Check for subsequent 594, 599, or 150 codes and compare transcript dates to client submission records. Confirm whether the return is simply delayed or if further follow-up is needed.

How does 597 differ from 594/599?

597 shows a return is pending, not yet processed. 594 means the return was filed, and 599 means the case is satisfied. 597 should be replaced by one of those once the IRS finishes processing.

How long does 597 stay on the transcript?

597 stays until the pending status resolves. If the return is stuck or rejected, it may persist for weeks or months. Once processed, it is replaced by 594, 599, or assessment codes.
